title: Have you ever read Enid Blyton books? - Quora

response.answer_text: Have you ever read Enid Blyton books? I was just about weaned on Enid Blyton books and loved them until I was about 10 or perhaps a little younger. I started with Noddy and Big Ears, went on to the Magic Faraway Tree when I was about five, and finished up with the Famous Five and the Secret Seven when I was a little older. I remember for several years I strongly identified with George of the Famous Five. I thought she was wonderful. A couple of years ago, I saw an offer on Amazon Kindle for three of the books and bought them, and went for a stroll down Memory Lane. I couldn’t believe what an objectionable little brat she seems to the adult me. No wonder I was clouted so often when I was a child. They were certainly fun for a kid to read, but I clearly didn’t have much taste.

Have I ever read Enid Blyton books? When I was 12, my father was transferred to a town near Frankfurt for two years. While there I met the most interesting girl, with a wild imagination. She was from the States, but had lived in Great Britain and was reading a book I hadn’t seen in the US. I think it was a Roald Dahl’s “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory”. We discovered we were both bookworms and she invited me to her fancy home where she introduced me to The Famous Five series. I think she had Eight and I borrowed them all. The adventures this crew went on were nothing I had read before and I couldn’t get enough. Through Cindy I also fell in love with Puffin books and even now, I attach a specific and unique scent to those beloved young adult paperbacks. Thanks for asking! I saw this a bit ago and didn’t know where on Quora the question went. I had to answer! Your question brought back the best of memories.

Hullo. I have. Many! They are a treasure trove of magical mysteries. They truly are for the kids. It allows young adults to be, at least through the story, be a part of an adventure. And, through the crucible of that adventure, they help develop the reading habit in kids. That’s important public service. She, Blyton, has blessed the world and warrants great respect and appreciation for her contributions.  Gaurang.

Ι have read a great number of them. When I was about 8 years old my mother bought for me most of The Secret Seven and The Famous Five series. And I remember truly enjoying them. They introduced me to the concept of a companionship, the joy of finding pleasure in simple things, the thrill of exploring and seeking answers to the mysteries of life, as well as the benefits of being bold and fearless, considering the world yours to explore and understand - and, as a boy growing up, prepare to conquer.  They also taught me what great fun a good mystery-adventure can be. Both reading and writing one.

Pretty much all of them for all ages. The most extraordinary aspect of her prolific output, beyond a lot of the virtues described in the other answers was that she produced books that were the best in category for every age group starting from 3 to 12 in the minds of parents, as well as children - boys and girls. She was a monster hit in India. Kids who could not afford to buy them would borrow well thumbed versions that had been kept in family closets for decades as a treasure. I buy them for my seven year old son. When 5 years old, he enjoyed the Noddy books for all of six months, and even the Amelia Jane stories about a naughty doll for a similar period. Now, alas, he has moved on to his primary passion of Star Wars. That's an amazing accomplishment for any author of children's books, unlikely to be ever repeated.

Timing couldn’t have been perfect for this question. Quick answer is that I am reading Famous five series by Enid Blyton, right now. Just finished first 3 books and onto 4 th now. I had bought the set of Famous five for my son. But when I was growing up, never had a chance to read Enid Blyton, Always read Nancy drew & Dr Who. But Enid Blyton books are perfect for young budding kids, as the language is easy to read and difficult words are introduced slowly. I have been enjoying the books and looking forward to have light reading in between Murakami and Lee Child work.

I read Enid Blyton’s “of Adventure” books, Castle of Adventure, Circus of Adventure, Mountain of Adventure, River of Adventure, Sea of Adventure, Ship of Adventure, and Valley of Adventure. Obviously I enjoyed them or I wouldn’t have bought them. Presumably I read more library books by her. It was a very long time ago, so I don’t remember them being racist or sexist or offensive.

Can I say something that others may not like? Hell yeah! I used to love them from the age of around four, until I read the magic Faraway tree when I was five. My obsession grew from there, Secret Seven, Famous Five, etc. In my opinion Enid Blyton had a way of drawing children in, and was one of the best children’s authors out there. Of course, now there are so many more, but I won’t forget Enid Blyton. ~Aesthetic

Well of course; they were preety much standard fare in the 60s. They don’t stand up all that well these days, being most definetly a product of the “things were so nice in the old days” school of thinking. Best bit though was a friend’s bookcase. Lined up in order he had Five go CampingFive have plenty of funFive get into TroubleThe Secret SevenThink about it for a while…

Yes, she is a classic - and her kids books are too. I read quite a few of her books when I was a kid in the late 60’s and early 70’s, when I was around 7–9. I enjoyed them. I would still recommend them as classics.

Yes, as a child I read many Enid Blyton books. A distant relative in the UK used to send them to me. When my husband and I lived in Germany near a UK forces base. There, we bought Enid Blyton’s “Noddy” books for our children.

Yes. When I was about twelve I read all the books in the Mallory Towers series. I also read The Naughtiest Girl in the School and a couple of other books from the series. These stories are about life in a boarding school. I never went to boarding school but I really enjoyed these books. I must have read some of the Noddy books, or had them read to me when I was a young child.

Yes, not many but they left a good impression. In fact I’ve bought a few at used book stores over the years and still reread them sometimes when I’m feeling down, I like spending an hour in a world where people are basically nice and life is simpler.

Excellent, optimistic books about intelligent, resourceful and mutually respectful and caring child detectives. Very “dated” culturally, to 1930s and 1950s Britain, but this adds to thier old fashioned charm.
I believe so, but it was a long time ago.
